questions.text: A patient with blood type A requires a blood transfusion. Which of the following blood types could they safely receive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A and O

 

Option B:

 

Individuals with blood type A have A antigens on their red blood cells and naturally occurring anti-B antibodies. They can receive type A (same antigens) or type O (no A or B antigens) blood. Type AB blood contains B antigens, which would react with the patient's anti-B antibodies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A and AB: Type AB blood contains B antigens, which would react with the recipient's anti-B antibodies, leading to a transfusion reaction.

 

Option C. A, B, and AB: Type B blood would also react with the recipient's anti-B antibodies.

 

Option D. Only A: While type A blood is compatible, type O is also safe for transfusion to a person with type A blood.

 

Educational objective:

 

Understanding ABO compatibility is crucial for safe blood transfusions.

choices.text: Addition of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to the H antigen
Addition of galactose (Gal) to the H antigen
Removal of fucose from the H antigen
Absence of both GalNAc and Gal on the H antigen

questions.text: Which of the following genetic modifications on chromosome 9 leads to the formation of the B antigen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Addition of galactose (Gal) to the H antigen

 

Option B:

 

The B antigen is formed by the addition of a galactose molecule to the terminal end of the H antigen. This is facilitated by specific glycosyltransferases encoded on chromosome 9.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Addition of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to the H antigen: This modification results in the formation of the A antigen.

 

Option C. Removal of fucose from the H antigen: While removal of fucose is a step in the formation of both A and B antigens, it's not the final step for the B antigen.

 

Option D. Absence of both GalNAc and Gal on the H antigen: This results in the O blood group, where neither A nor B antigens are present.

 

Educational objective:

 

The A and B antigens are formed by modifications of the H antigen.

questions.text: Which of the following Rh antigens is the most immunogenic, leading to the highest risk of alloimmunization in Rh-negative individuals?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D antigen

 

Option D:

 

The D antigen is the most immunogenic of the Rh antigens, meaning it is most likely to trigger an immune response in Rh-negative individuals if they are exposed to Rh-positive blood. This is why Rh immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) is given to Rh-negative mothers to prevent sensitization to the D antigen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. C antigen: While the C antigen can be immunogenic, it is less so than the D antigen. Anti-C antibodies are relatively common, but they usually cause milder reactions than anti-D antibodies.

 

Option B. E antigen: Similar to the C antigen, the E antigen is immunogenic but less so than the D antigen. Anti-E antibodies are less common than anti-C antibodies and generally cause less severe reactions.

 

Option C. c antigen: The c antigen is the most common Rh antigen (80% of the population expresses it). However, it is considered weakly immunogenic, and anti-c antibodies are relatively rare.

 

Educational objective:

 

The D antigen is the most immunogenic, posing the highest risk of alloimmunization in Rh-negative individuals. Understanding the Rh system and its genetic basis is crucial for safe blood transfusions and preventing complications like hemolytic disease of the newborn.

choices.text: A, B, AB, and O - all types

questions.text: A patient with blood type AB positive requires a plasma transfusion. Which of the following blood types could be safely used as a source of fresh frozen plasma (FFP)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only AB

 

Option B.

 

  • AB individuals have both A and B antigens on their red blood cells but lack anti-A and anti-B antibodies in their plasma.
  • They can only receive plasma from donors who also lack anti-A and anti-B antibodies, which would be other AB individuals.

 

Educational objective:

 

Plasma compatibility is based on the absence of antibodies in the donor plasma that could react with the recipient's RBC antigens.

questions.text: In a trauma setting where blood typing is not immediately available, which blood type is typically used for emergency transfusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) O negative

 

Option D:

 

  • In emergencies, O negative packed red blood cells are used because they are considered the safest option for transfusion when the recipient's blood type is unknown.
  • This is because O negative blood lacks A and B antigens, minimizing the risk of a transfusion reaction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. AB negative: AB negative blood contains both A and B antigens, which could cause a serious reaction if the recipient has antibodies against either of these antigens.

 

Option B. A positive: A positive blood contains A antigens and the Rh factor, both of which could trigger a transfusion reaction in a recipient without these antigens.

 

Option C. B positive: B positive blood contains B antigens and the Rh factor, making it unsuitable for transfusion to individuals who lack these antigens.

 

Educational objective:

 

O negative blood is the universal red blood cell donor, making it the preferred choice for emergency transfusions.

choices.text: B positive and B negative
AB negative and O negative
B negative and O positive

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with blood type B negative requires an emergency blood transfusion due to severe hemorrhage. Which of the following blood types could be safely administered?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Only B negative

 

Option D:

 

B negative individuals can only receive blood from B negative (same type) or O negative (universal donor). Other options are incorrect as they contain A or Rh antigens that could cause a transfusion reaction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. B positive and B negative: B positive blood has the RhD antigen, which the recipient could develop antibodies against, leading to potential complications in future transfusions or pregnancies.

 

Option B. AB negative and O negative: AB negative blood contains A antigens, which would react with the recipient's anti-A antibodies.

 

Option C. B negative and O positive: O positive blood contains the RhD antigen, which the recipient could develop antibodies against.

 

Educational objective:

 

It is crucial to match both ABO and Rh blood groups to ensure safe transfusions, especially in emergency situations.

questions.text: A patient experiences a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR) 5 days after a blood transfusion. Which of the following blood group systems is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kidd

 

Option B:

 

The Kidd blood group system is known for its association with delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions (DHTR), often occurring days after the transfusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Kell: While Kell antibodies can cause severe hemolytic reactions, these are typically acute rather than delayed.

 

Option C. MNS: MNS antibodies can cause delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions, but they are relatively rare compared to Kidd antibodies.

 

Option D. Lewis: Lewis antibodies are naturally occurring and typically of the IgM isotype, which are generally not considered clinically significant in transfusions.

 

Educational objective:

 

Kidd antibodies are typically IgG and can cause severe delayed reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following blood group antigens can be acquired by donor red blood cells (RBCs) soon after transfusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lewis

 

Option D:

 

Lewis antigens are plasma antigens that can adsorb onto RBCs after transfusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Duffy: Duffy antigens are also integral membrane proteins of red blood cells and are not passively acquired.

 

Option B. Kidd: Kidd antigens are similarly integral membrane proteins and are not acquired from the plasma.

 

Option C. MNS: MNS antigens are part of the red blood cell glycophorin complex and are not acquired from the plasma.

 

Educational objective:

 

Lewis antigens are not intrinsic to RBCs but are acquired from the plasma.

choices.text: DARC (Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines)

questions.text: Which of the following antigen is resistant to P. vivax/knowlesi?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DARC (Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines)

 

Option B:

 

Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines (DARC): The DARC acts as a receptor for both chemokines and Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium knowlesi malaria parasites. Individuals lacking this receptor (Duffy-negative phenotype) are resistant to these types of malaria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. K/k: Kell antigens are a group of antigens found on red blood cells. They are not involved in malaria resistance.

 

Option C. Lewis Ag: Lewis antigens are present in body fluids and can be adsorbed onto red blood cells. They do not play a role in malaria resistance.

 

Option D. A antigen: The A antigen is part of the ABO blood group system and determines blood type. It has no relationship to malaria susceptibility.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Duffy antigen receptor for chemokines (DARC) is essential for P. vivax and P. knowlesi malaria parasites to invade red blood cells. Individuals without this receptor are naturally resistant to these types of malaria.

choices.text: Determine the blood type of the donor
Determine the blood type of the recipient
Detect unexpected antibodies in the recipient's serum
Ensure compatibility between donor red blood cells and recipient serum

questions.text: What is the primary goal of a blood crossmatch?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ensure compatibility between donor red blood cells and recipient serum

 

Option D:

 

The crossmatch is a critical final step before a blood transfusion. It directly tests the compatibility between the donor's red blood cells and the recipient's serum to prevent life-threatening transfusion reactions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Determine the blood type of the donor: Blood typing is a separate test performed prior to crossmatching to determine the donor's ABO and Rh blood group.

 

Option B. Determine the blood type of the recipient: Similar to donor typing, recipient blood typing is done prior to crossmatching.

 

Option C. Detect unexpected antibodies in the recipient's serum: While crossmatching can detect unexpected antibodies, this is primarily the purpose of an antibody screen, a separate test performed before crossmatching.

 

Educational objective:

 

Crossmatching is essential for ensuring safe blood transfusions.

questions.text: A patient's blood sample is mixed with Anit-A/B/D and the findings are shown below. What is the patient's blood type?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B+

 

Option B:

 

Agglutination with anti-B indicates the presence of B antigens on the red blood cells. Agglutination with anti-D indicates the presence of the Rh factor (positive). No agglutination with anti-A indicates the absence of A antigens.

 

Educational objective:

 

Blood typing is determined by the presence or absence of specific antigens on the surface of red blood cells.

questions.text: A patient's blood sample is mixed with Anit-A/B/D and the findings are shown below. What is the patient's blood type?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) O-

 

Option D:

 

The absence of agglutination with anti-A, anti-B, and anti-D antibodies indicates the absence of A, B, and Rh antigens on the red blood cells.

 

Educational objective:

 

O- blood type is the universal donor of red blood cells.
